constraints_details.constraints_layer_description: NEIPOL Name: MC1  Maldens and Coombe
AIRCZ Type:: Gatwick Airport Wind Turbine Consultation Zone:Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Gatwick Airport Limited, 7th Floor Destinations Place, London Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH06 0NP

description: Erection of two storey side extension and alterations to fenestration and boundary treatment. Installation of 3 x air conditioning units on rear facade and roof light  in front roof slope. (Retrospective application)
decision_conditions: The facing materials used in the development to which this permission relates shall match those of the existing building(s) unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The rating level of the noise determined by the cumulative sound emissions of the plant hereby permitted shall be at least 5dBA lower than the existing background noise level at any given time of operation. The noise levels shall be measured or predicted 1m externally to any window at the nearest residential facade. Measurements and assessment shall be made according to British Standard 4142:2014.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with "Environmental Noise Impact Assessment" Rev 01 dated 17 August 2020.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises Coombe Girls' School & Sixth Form Centre. The site is bounded by Clarence Avenue to the south and Darley Drive to the west with the site entrance accessed via Clarence Avenue.The existing school comprises a mix of one and two storey buildings with associated car parking, games courts and playing fields. The surrounding area is predominantly residential in character and appearance consisting of two storey semi-detached dwellings. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Proposal Removal of part boundary wall for pedestrian access route to access Sixth Form Centre from Darley Drive. Erection of 2 nos brick piers on either side of the new boundary opening.Representations67 properties were notified of the proposal.Two representations have been received with comments summarised as follows:- Access or traffic problems- Car parking issues- The proposal is incompatible with road safety on Darley Drive.Officer Comment: The above concerns would be addressed with the report.Any comments relating to the highways for example: the appropriate speed limit on Darley Drive, additional crossing point or road marks should be addressed to the Council's Highways department as they are not planning matters and cannot be taken into consideration when determining this application. Kingston Council has launched a Let's Talk hub where residents can raise various issues and share their comments and suggestions about how to improve various aspects of the borough including our Highways programmes, information about this can be found on the council's website or access directly https://kingstonletstalk.co.uk/hub-page/our-streetsConsultationsRBK Highways and Transportation - no objections:'The proposed new pedestrian access would reduce potential for person/vehicle contact and make the school more accessible by bus.The applicant should note that the footway/highway must not be blocked or used for materials storage without the necessary highway licence being obtained beforehand. Any incidental damage to the footway must be reported and the applicant would be responsible for covering in full any associated costs incurred by Highways in remedying such damage.'Transport for London - No comments offeredThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Highway SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed new pedestrian access route would involve removal of part of the existing boundary wall, installation of two brick piers on either side of the new opening and new metal rails and provision of new steps. The proposal would provide a new access from Darley Drive to the schools facility, as currently it is being accessed mainly via the existing car park. It is noted that the proposed design and height of the proposed brick piers would match the existing ones. Due to the proposed design, scale and materials the proposal is considered to be in-keeping with the host building and the existing boundary treatment. As such, there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development due to its siting and modest scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Highway SafetyParagraph 111 of the NPPF, 2021 states that development should only be prevented or refused on transport grounds if there would be an unacceptable impact on highway safety, or where the residual cumulative impacts of development are severe. Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 requires development proposals to have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety and ensure they are not adversely affected. It is noted that the RBK Highways and Transportation Officer raised no objections to the proposal.Given the siting, scale and nature (additional pedestrian access to the school's facility) of the proposal, it is considered that it would not result in an unacceptable impact on the local highway network.Concerns have been raised in written representations that the proposal would result in the following:- Access or traffic problems- Car parking issues- The proposal is incompatible with road safety on Darley Drive.Officers note that the proposal is for an additional pedestrian access to the school's facility, therefore it would not necessarily result in material and unacceptable impact on the existing car parking facilities or result in increased traffic issues or safety issues.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a mid terrace dwelling located within the Flood Zone 2. Proposal Erection of a part single and part double-storey rear extension and erection of a new porch.Relevant planning history:22/03652/CPU  Erection of single-storey detached outbuilding 5.5m x 5.5m with a maximum height of 2.5m granted on 17.01.202322/03313/CPU Erection of single storey rear extension and a new outbuilding granted on 12.12.202222/03239/PAEXT  Erection of single storey rear extension (4.5m in depth, maximum height of 2.8m and eaves height of 2.6m) granted on 21.11.202222/03214/HOU Erection of single storey rear extension granted on 13.12.202222/02659/HOU Erection of a part single and part double storey rear extension and new porch granted on 11.10.2022Consultations23 properties were notified of the proposal.  Three representation has been received with comments summarised as follows:- Inadequate landscaping/means of enclosure (ownership of a land to the rear)- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Loss of light/sunlight- Noise Ownership matters are not considered to be material planning consideration, therefore they cannot be included within the assessment. The other concerns will be addressed within the report. The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Flood Risk;and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed single storey rear extension would project approximately 4.5m beyond the rear elevation and would have eaves height of approximately 2.6m. The two storey element would project 3m beyond the rear building line. It is acknowledged that the proposed single storey rear extension would not be strictly in accordance with Policy Guidance 33 of the Council's Residential Design SPD with regards to the recommended depths which in this case are up to 3.5m. However, it is noted that the application site benefits from permitted development rights for larger home extensions which is considered a fallback position in this case. Therefore, having regard to the 'fallback' position, no objections are raised with respect to this element. Similarly, the two storey rear extension has the benefit of planning permission via application 22/02659/HOU. In essence, this application seeks to combine the approvals granted via 22/02659/HOU and 22/03239/PAEXT, albeit with a modified roof design to the single storey rear extension. Officers note that the neighbouring properties benefit from the single storey rear extensions, it is considered that the proposed development would be acceptable in terms of its scale, mass and bulk in relation to the host dwelling and the adjoining terraced properties. The proposed rear extension would not be visible within the street view, therefore there would be no impact on the existing street scene. The proposed front porch due to its scale, design and materials is considered to be in-keeping with the host dwelling and  the surrounding area. As such, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is noted that the adjoining property No 73 Addison Gardens benefits from planning permission 20/01551/HOU for Erection of porch, part single/part double storey rear and side extensions that according to Building Control records has been implemented. The proposed extension would extend approximately 1.7m beyond the adjoining extension. No 69 Addison Gardens shows an existing rear extension.As such it is considered that the proposed rear extension due to its scale and siting would not result in an overbearing effect or sense on enclosure, loss of light or loss of privacy.  The proposal would pass the 45 degree rule in relation to both adjoining properties and therefore it would not result in an unacceptable loss of daylight in relation to these properties. Flood RiskPolicy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.Officer Comment: The application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2. Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. The submitted plans indicate that floor levels within the proposed development would be set no lower than the main dwelling and appropriate mitigation measures would be implemented as part of the proposed development which are considered acceptable and in accordance with Policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details are agreed and that Condition 3 (Structural Method Statement) of listed building consent 21/01116/LBC is hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.
It is unclear what is being applied for. Please could you clarify the nature of the proposal. We can then provide a correct fee quote.

The fee required for your pre-planning application is £2130. Payment can be made online via Kingston Council's website, via our Contact Centre on 020 8547 5002, or by cheque made payable to Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames.

A Site Notice is required to publicise the application as the site address is in a Conservation Area. Please can you advise us of a postal address to which we can send the laminated Site Notice; so that it can be posted up on site?
